string.name: t
string.br: Thyroid is an Autoimmune Disease. It affects the Thyroid gland, which is located in the neck.
The thyroid secretes several hormones, collectively called as Thyroid hormones. By checking the level of these hormones, one can say if they are suffering from this disorder or not.

br.b: There are basically two kinds of this disorder.

resources.string:
It is also known as Underactive Thyroid as it produces less hormones than the normal. 
 The main Cause is Iodine Deficiency. 
 Its Symptoms Include: 
 -Weight Gain
 -Constipation
 -Myxedema (swelling on face or eyebrows)
 -Low Heart Rate
 -High Blood Pressure
 -Change in Skin color - Pale yellow
 -Dry skin
 -Intolerance to Cold
 -In females - Infertility

In youngsters having very low production of the hormones, these symptoms can be seen: 
 -Cretinism
 -Slow Reflexes

It is also known as Overactive Thyroid as it produces more hormones than the normal. 
 Its Symptoms Include: 
 -Weight Loss
 -Diarrhoea
 -High Heart Rate
 -High Blood Pressure
 -Palpitation
 -Excessive Sweating
 -Intolerance to Heat
 -Exophthalmos
In people with Heart condition, their heart condition keeps getting worse. \n

resources.string: \tBabies are born with protection against some diseases because their mothers pass antibodies (proteins made by the body to fight disease) to them before birth. Breastfed babies continue to get more antibodies in breast milk. But in both cases, the protection is temporary. \n \tVaccination is a way to create immunity to (protection from) some diseases. This is done by using small amounts of a killed or weakened germ that causes the disease.

\tBefore leaving the hospital or birthing center, your baby receives the first of 3 doses of the vaccine that protects against Hepatitis B. \n \tHepatitis B virus can cause chronic swelling of the liver and possible lifelong complications.\n \tIt’s important to protect infants and young children from hepatitis B because they are more likely than adults to develop incurable chronic (long term) infection that can result in liver damage and liver cancer.

Protect your baby by providing immunity early in life. Starting at 1 to 2 months of age, your baby receives the following vaccines to develop immunity from potentially harmful diseases:
 -Hepatitis B (2nd dose)
 -Diphtheria, tetanus, and whooping cough (pertussis) (DTaP)
 -Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
 -Polio (IPV)
 -Pneumococcal (PCV)
 -Rotavirus (RV)

Protect your baby by providing immunity early in life. Stay on track with the recommended vaccine schedule. At 4 months of age, your baby receives the following vaccines to develop immunity from potentially harmful diseases:
 -Diphtheria, tetanus, and whooping cough (pertussis) (DTaP)
 -Polio (IPV)
 -Pneumococcal 
(PCV) -Rotavirus (RV)
 -Hepatitis B (HepB)

Protect your baby by providing immunity early in life. Stay on track with the recommended vaccine schedule. At 6 months of age, your baby receives the following vaccines to develop immunity from potentially harmful diseases:
 -Diphtheria, tetanus, and whooping cough (pertussis) (DTaP)
 -Polio (IPV)
 -Pneumococcal (PCV)
 -Rotavirus (RV)
 -Hepatitis B (HepB)

There are usually no vaccinations scheduled between 7 and 11 months of age. However, if your baby has missed an earlier vaccination, now is a good time to “catch up.”\n
Babies 6 months and older should receive flu vaccination every flu season.\n

Protect your baby by providing immunity early in life. Stay on track with the recommended vaccine schedule. At 4 months of age, your baby receives the following vaccines to develop immunity from potentially harmful diseases:
 -Polio (IPV)
 -Pneumococcal (PCV)
 -Rotavirus (RV)
 -Hepatitis B (HepB)
 -Hepatitis A (HepA)
 -Measles, mumps, rubella (MMR)
 -Chickenpox (Varicella)


 	Additionally, children should receive flu vaccination every flu season.

Between 2 and 10 years of age, your child should visit the doctor once a year for check-ups.\n
Additionally, children should receive flu vaccination every flu season.\n

There are four vaccines recommended for preteens—these vaccines help protect your children, their friends, and their family members.
 -Meningococcal conjugate vaccine
 -HPV vaccine
 -Tdap
 -Flu vaccine every flu season


 	Additionally, children should receive flu vaccination every flu season.
